edu.rit.pj2

Class ObjectParallelForLoop<W>

  • java.lang.Object
    • edu.rit.pj2.ParallelStatement
      • edu.rit.pj2.ParallelForLoop
        • edu.rit.pj2.ObjectParallelForLoop<W>
  • Type Parameters:
    W - Data type of the work items.

    public class ObjectParallelForLoop<W>
extends ParallelForLoop
    Class ObjectParallelForLoop provides a work sharing parallel for loop executed by multiple threads, looping over the work items in a WorkQueue. An object parallel for loop is constructed by the parallelFor(WorkQueue) method of class Task.

    Programming pattern. To execute a parallel for loop over a series of work items in the main() method of a Task, follow this pattern: 

     public class MyTask extends Task
     {
     public void main (String[] args)
         {
         WorkQueue<W> queue = new WorkQueue<W>();
         parallelFor (queue) .exec (new ObjectLoop<W>()
             {
             // Thread-local variable declarations (optional)
             public void start()
                 {
                 // One-time thread-local initialization (optional method)
                 }
             public void run (W workitem)
                 {
                 // Loop body code for workitem (required method)
                 }
             public void finish()
                 {
                 // One-time thread-local finalization (optional method)
                 }
             });
         }
     }

    W is the data type of the work items. queue is a WorkQueue of work items to be processed in parallel. Call the work queue's add() method to add a work item to the work queue. Work items may be added to the work queue at any time by any thread; for example: by the task main thread before starting the parallel for loop; by a separate thread running concurrently with the parallel for loop; or in the parallel for loop body itself.

    Parallel thread team. The parallel for loop is executed by a team of threads. The number of threads is given by the threads property of the enclosing task (see the threads() method of class Task). The default is one thread for each core of the machine on which the program is running. The default can be overridden as follows: 

         parallelFor (queue) .threads (threads) .exec (new ObjectLoop<W>() ...

    Parallel loop body. The threads execute the methods in the inner ObjectLoop class. For further information about how the parallel for loop executes, see class ObjectLoop.

    See Also:
    ParallelStatement, ParallelForLoop, ObjectLoop

      void exec(ObjectLoop<W> loop)
      Execute this parallel for loop with the loop body specified by the given ObjectLoop object.

      Set this parallel for loop's threads property.

    • Method Detail

      • threads

        public ObjectParallelForLoop<W> threads(int threads)
        Set this parallel for loop's threads property. The threads property specifies the number of threads that will execute this parallel for loop. The default is the threads property of the enclosing task. For further information, see the threads() method of class Task.
        Parameters:
        threads - Number of threads (≥ 1), Task.THREADS_EQUALS_CORES, or Task.DEFAULT_THREADS.
        Returns:
        This parallel for loop object.
        Throws:
        IllegalArgumentException - (unchecked exception) Thrown if threads is illegal.

      • exec

        public void exec(ObjectLoop<W> loop)
        Execute this parallel for loop with the loop body specified by the given ObjectLoop object.
        Parameters:
        loop - Loop object.
        Throws:
        NullPointerException - (unchecked exception) Thrown if loop is null.
